significance: Marks the Sun’s entry into Capricorn, beginning warmer days.
Symbolically ends the coldest month in hill regions.
legendsAndBeliefs: Connected to Bhisma Pitamah’s moksha in the Mahabharata.
Holy bath believed to cleanse sins.
ritualsAndObservances: Family feasts featuring til ko laddu, chaaku, sweet potatoes, yams.
foodsAndActivities: Sesame (til) sweets for warmth, possible local fairs.

significance: Dedicated to Goddess Saraswati, patroness of knowledge, music, arts.
Auspicious day for learning.
ritualsAndObservances: Books and musical instruments placed on the altar.
Many children learn their first letters (Hate Lakhe).
foodsAndActivities: Sweets (sel roti, halwa), cultural programs, poetry recitals.

significance: Honors Lord Shiva, associated with creation and destruction.
Believed to be Shiva’s wedding night or day of cosmic dance.
ritualsAndObservances: All-night vigils, fasting or minimal food.
foodsAndActivities: Large pilgrim gatherings at Pashupatinath Temple.

significance: Festival of colors, celebrating the onset of spring.
Symbolic victory of good over evil (Holika & Prahlad legend).
foodsAndActivities: Gujiya (sweet dumplings), local variations in Tarai communities.
Emphasis on using safe, natural colors.

significance: Birth anniversary of Lord Rama.
Tied to the epic Ramayana.
ritualsAndObservances: Janakpur hosts chariot processions of Rama-Sita idols.

significance: Smaller 'spring' Dashain dedicated to Goddess Durga.
Less grand but still important for families.
rituals: Worship at Durga temples, sometimes animal sacrifice.

significance: Marks the start of the Bikram Sambat calendar.
ritualsAndObservances: Exchanging good wishes, family picnics, temple visits.
localTieIns: Coincides with Bisket Jatra in Bhaktapur.

significance: Commemorates the birth, enlightenment, and death of Lord Buddha.
ritualsAndObservances: Peaceful processions, chanting sutras, lighting butter lamps.

significance: Day to honor mothers (living or deceased).
ritualsAndObservances: Gifts, special meals for living mothers.
Pilgrimage to Mata Tirtha for ancestor rites if mother is deceased.

name: Ropain Jatra (Asar 15)
location: Rural districts, outskirts of Kathmandu Valley

significance: Marks the start of rice planting season.
ritualsAndObservances: Farmers gather in muddy fields, transplant seedlings.
Singing folk songs, mud-play, and dance.
foodTradition: Dahi Chiura (curd & beaten rice) to keep cool and energized.

significance: Worship of serpent deities (Nagas).
Believed to ensure protection from snakes and water shortages.
ritualsAndObservances: People paste snake pictures on doorways.
Offerings of milk/rice to serpent gods.

name: Gai Jatra
month: August (day after Janai Purnima in Kathmandu Valley)

significance: Commemorates deceased family members of the past year, guided by a sacred cow.
Known for comedic street performances to ease grief.
ritualsAndObservances: Processions of children or cow effigies.

significance: Renewal of the sacred thread (janai).
Tying raksha bandhan on wrists for protection.
ritualsAndObservances: Priests tie raksha bandhan on devotees.
Kwati (mixed bean soup) is a special dish.

significance: Women-centric festival dedicated to Goddess Parvati & Lord Shiva.
Prayers for marital bliss and husband's well-being.
Honors fathers, living or deceased.
ritualsAndObservances: Gifts, special meals for living fathers.
Ancestor rites at Gokarneshwar if father is deceased.

significance: Celebrates Indra, the god of rain, and includes Kumari chariot processions.
The grandest Hindu festival, celebrating Goddess Durga’s victory.
Major family reunions, blessings, feasts.
keyDays: Maha Ashtami & Mahanavami: Intense Durga worship, animal sacrifices in some areas.
Vijaya Dashami (day 10): Receiving tika & jamara from elders, major travel day.
Kojagrat Purnima (day 15): Worship of Laxmi, staying awake for prosperity.
foodsAndActivities: Goat meat (khasi), sel roti, sweets, card games, kite flying.

significance: “Yamapanchak,” festival of lights honoring various animals, Laxmi, and sibling bond.
dayByDay: 3) Gai Tihar & Laxmi Puja (cows, goddess of wealth).
highlights: Sel roti, lights, marigold garlands, Deusi-Bhailo singing.

name: Chhath Puja
location: Riverbanks in Tarai, also Kathmandu (Bagmati, etc.)

significance: Dedicated to Surya (Sun God) for health, prosperity.
Major festival in the Tarai region.
outline: Nahay Khay, Kharna, Sandhya Arghya, Usha Arghya.
Devotees fast, offer fruits and sweets to the setting/rising sun.

significance: Scattering of sat biu (seven types of seeds) to honor departed souls.
ritualsAndObservances: Morning procession scattering seeds at shrines.

name: Yomari Punhi
month: November/December (Full Moon of Thinla in Nepal Sambat)

significance: Celebrates the end of the rice harvest.
Honors Goddess Annapurna.
ritualsAndObservances: Making Yomari (steamed dumplings with sweet fillings).

significance: Tamang lunar New Year.
Showcases Tamang heritage with music & dance.
Marks the Sherpa (and Himalayan) lunar new year.
Religious observances in monasteries.
keyActivities: Khapse (fried pastry), butter tea, family gatherings.

significance: Gurung lunar New Year.
Emphasis on clan unity, ancestor remembrance.
celebrations: Feasts with sel roti, achaar, millet bread.

significance: Seasonal migration celebrations (uphill in summer, downhill in winter).
Sakela or Sili dances honoring nature & ancestors.
Re-enacts the wedding of Lord Rama & Goddess Sita.
mainObservances: Grand procession (barat) from Ram Temple to Janaki Temple.
Symbolic marriage ceremony at Janaki Temple.

significance: Dedicated to Goddess Gaura (Parvati), focusing on marital fidelity.
ritualsAndObservances: Women perform collective pujas, share blessings.

significance: Harvest thanksgiving, offering first produce to deities & ancestors.
Tibetan Buddhist festival for world peace, removing negative forces.
keyElements: Sand mandala creation, Wong (empowerment), Cham (masked dances), Fire Puja.

significance: Celebrates deity Dorje Jono’s victory over demons causing drought.
dayByDayHighlights: Masked dances narrate the story of warding off evil, prayers for rains.

significance: Sacred month of pilgrimage, reflection, and generosity.
observances: Early-morning visits to stupas with Gunla baja.
Fasting, almsgiving, art exhibitions of paubha or manuscripts.

deitySignificance: Seto Machhindranath (Karunamaya) for rain and compassion.
rituals: Chariot construction and pulling through old city lanes.

deitySignificance: Rato Machhindranath (Bungadya), god of rain and harvest.
timelineAndObservances: Tall chariot pulled through Patan neighborhoods.
Bhoto Jatra finale at Jawalakhel (display of jewel-studded vest).

significance: Local new year festival involving legendary serpent tales.
keyEvents: Erection & lowering of Yoshi (pole) as an omen.

deitySignificance: Tantric Buddhist goddess representing supreme knowledge.

significance: Worship of local mother goddesses and protective deities.
observances: Family feasts, inviting married daughters home.
Processions with deity replicas and light offerings.

celebrations: Deity procession, possible animal sacrifices, communal feasts.

significance: Historical dance-drama from Malla era.
Depicts Hindu mythological tales.
Locals worship Sikali Mata instead of mainstream Durga forms.
uniqueAspects: Masked dances in open fields, no animal sacrifices.

significance: Driving away malevolent spirits before monsoon.
rituals: House cleaning, installing fresh protective charms.

name: Matya
month: August (day after Gai Jatra in Patan)

significance: A festival of lights commemorating departed ancestors.
observances: Long barefoot procession, lighting candles/incense at numerous shrines.

significance: Display of ancestral swords (khadga).
Ritual dances for goddesses like Bhadrakali, Mahakali.
celebrations: Devi Naach with costumed dancers blessing the community.

name: Siruwa Parwa (Tharu New Year)
month: Mid-April (varies), or around Maghe Sankranti for some

significance: Tharu New Year or harvest festival (depending on subgroup).
ritualsAndObservances: Folk dances (jhumra, dhamar), feasts with local produce.

significance: Horse festival to subdue the demon Gurumapa.
Historically showcased cavalry skills to royals.
keyObservances: Military parades, horse races, government dignitaries in attendance.

significance: Pilgrimage to Khaptad Baba’s ashram.
Spiritual renewal in pristine natural setting.
activities: Treks, setting up camps, morning/evening aarti in the forest meadows.

significance: Celebrations of agricultural cycles, reverence for ancestors.
danceDetails: Dhan Nach (Rai): group sword-like dance steps.
Chyabrung Nach (Limbu): rhythmic drumming with large chyabrung drums.

significance: Thanksgiving to water deities after harvest.
observances: Small fairs with handicrafts and local produce.

significance: Honoring local protective deities.
Often aligns with Gaura Parva.
celebrations: Folk dances, stalls selling crafts, communal feasts.

significance: Devotion to Goddess Swasthani & Lord Shiva.
Emphasizes marital fidelity, dedication, moral virtues.
observances: Many women fast, break it on the final full moon day.

significance: Month-long Buddhist retreat with morning pilgrimages, almsgiving.

name: Krishna Janmashtami
location: Nationwide; main temple at Patan (Krishna Mandir)

significance: Birth of Lord Krishna, 8th avatar of Vishnu.
ritualsAndObservances: Fasting until midnight, bhajan singing, temple gatherings.

name: Sithi Nakha
month: May/June (6th day of bright half of Jestha)

significance: Dedicated to Lord Kumar (Kartikeya).
Day for cleaning wells, ponds before monsoon.
activities: Well-cleaning, communal efforts for fresh water.
Cooking wo (lentil pancakes) and other Newar delicacies.

significance: Commemorates Lord Ganesh’s birth, remover of obstacles.
keyObservances: Offerings of modak, laddu, fruits (Ganesh’s favorites).

name: Nepal Sambat New Year (Mha Puja Day)

significance: Marks the start of Newar cultural/lunar calendar (Nepal Sambat).
Mha Puja: Ritual cleansing, worship of the self.
observances: Mandalas for each family member, blessings, and feasting.

significance: Tharu version of Holi, celebrating spring with unique cultural flair.

name: Loktantra Diwas, Republic Day, Constitution Day
month: Various (Loktantra: Apr 24, Republic: May 28, Constitution: Sep 20)

significance: Commemorate Nepal’s key political milestones.
